case_name: S. Govinda Menon v. Union of India and State of Kerala

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1366 of 1966 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated January 5, 1966 of the Kerala High Court in Original Petition No.1 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1366 of 1966. Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 5, 1966 of the Kerala High Court in Original Petition No.1 of 1964.

facts.text: The appellant, Sri S. Govinda Menon, is a member of the Indian Administrative Service.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Sri S. Govinda Menon is a member of the Indian Administrative Service. He was the First.

facts.text: Sri S. Govinda Menon was the First Member of the Board of Revenue, Kerala State and was holding the post of Commissioner of Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments.

anchor.surface_text: He was the First. Member of the Board of Revenue, Kerala State and was holding the post of Commissioner of Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments.

facts.text: Kerala Government instituted preliminary enquiries based on petitions containing allegations of misconduct against the appellant in discharge of duties as Commissioner and started disciplinary proceedings and placed him under suspension under rule 7 of the All India Services Discipline and Appeal Rules, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of certain petitions companytaining allegations of misconduct against the appellant in the discharge of his duties as Commissioner the Kerala Government instituted certain preliminary enquiries and thereafter started disciplinary proceedings against the appellant and also placed him under suspension under rule 7 of the All India Services  Discipline and Appeal  Rules, 1955, hereinafter called the Rules.

facts.text: A copy of the charges together with a statement of certain allegations was served on the appellant who filed a written statement of defence.

anchor.surface_text: A companyy of the charges together with a statement of certain allegations was served on the appellant who thereafter filed a written statement of defence.

facts.text: Government passed orders that appellant's explanation was unacceptable and charges should be enquired into by an Enquiry Officer under rule 5 of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: After perusing the written statement the Government passed orders that his explanation was unacceptable and that the charges should be enquired into by an Enquiry Officer to be appointed under rule 5 of the Rules.

facts.text: Sri T. N. S. Raghavan, a retired I.C.S. Officer, was appointed to hold the inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly Sri T. N. S. Raghavan a retired I.C.S. Officer was appointed to hold the inquiry.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition before Kerala High Court praying for certiorari to quash proceedings and mandamus to allow him to function as First Member of Board of Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed the present writ petition before the High Court of Kerala praying for grant of a writ of certiorari to quash the proceedings initiated against, him and for a writ of mandwmus calling upon. respondent No. 2, State of Kerala, to allow him to function as the. First Member of the Board of Revenue.

facts.text: No application for stay was made and no order of stay was passed by High Court, so Sri T. N. S. Raghavan proceeded with inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: As numberapplication for stay was made and as numberorder of stay Was passed by the High Court Sri T. N. S. Raghavan proceeded with the inquiry and submitted his report to the Union Government

facts.text: Sri T. N. S. Raghavan submitted report to Union Government finding appellant guilty of charges 1 to 4 and 9.

anchor.surface_text: and submitted his report to the Union Government finding the appellant guilty of charges 1 to 4 and 9.

facts.text: Union of India issued Show Cause Notice Ex. P-9 after consideration of the report.

anchor.surface_text: The union of India, after companysideration of the report, issued a Show Cause Notice Ex. P-9.

facts.text: Appellant filed application for amendment of writ petition to include writ of prohibition restraining Union of India from proceeding further on Show Cause Notice and quashing it.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter filed an application before the High Court for amendment of the writ petition. The prayer in this amended petition was for the issue of a writ of prohibition restraining the first respondent Union of India-from proceeding further in pursuance of the Show Cause Notice and also for quashing the same.

facts.text: High Court allowed amendment application.

anchor.surface_text: The application for amendment was allowed by the High Court.

facts.text: Kerala High Court dismissed the writ petition by majority on January 5, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought, by certificate, against the judgment of the High Court of Kerala dated January 5, 1966 dismissing Original Petition No.1 of 1964 filed by the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant was Commissioner from 1-2-1957 to 19-10-1962.

anchor.surface_text: You were the Commissioner H. R. C. E.  Admn.  Department from 1-2-1957 to 19-10-62.

facts.text: Charges 1 to 4 relate to appellant's conduct in sanctioning 30 leases of private forest lands of 5 Devaswoms: Pulpally Devaswom, Kallaikulangara Emoor Bhagavathi Temple, Nadivilla Vallathu Devaswom, Kottiyor Devaswom, Mundayanparamba Devaswom.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary at this stage to set out the charges leveled against the appellant. Charges 1 to 4 relate mainly to the companyduct of the appellant in sanctioning 30 leases regarding the private forest lands of 5 Devaswoms and charge No. 9 companycerns the refusal by the appellant to attend a companyference companyvened by the Chief Secretary to companysider certain important matters companynected with the national emergency.

facts.text: In 17 of the leases relating to first charge, period is 36 years; in one case 96 years; in rest 99 years; total area over 50,000 acres.

anchor.surface_text: In 17 of the leases relating to the first charge the period of the lease is 36 years. In one case the period is 96 years and in the rest of the leases the period of lease is 99 years. The total area companyered by all the leases companyes to over 50,000 acres.

facts.text: Charge 9 concerns refusal by appellant to attend conference convened by Chief Secretary on 29-10-1962 to consider matters connected with national emergency.

anchor.surface_text: Charges 1 to 4 and 9 read as follows That you, Shri S. Govinda Menon, I.A.S., while employed in the Government. Service as member, Board of Revenue and Commissioner, H. C. E.  Administration  Department from 1- 2-1957 to 19-10-1962 issued sanctions granting leases of extensive and valuable forest lands belonging to the Devaswoms under your companytrol as Commissioner such as  1  Pulpally Devaswom, Kallaikulangara Emoor Bhagavathi Temple, Nadivilla Vallathu Devaswom,  4  Kottiyor Devaswom,  5  Mundayanparamba Devaswom etc.,

facts.text: Mathew, J. rejected appellant's objections on jurisdiction and held respondents had power to proceed with inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the arguments advanced on both sides, Mathew, J. rejected the objections raised by the appellant regarding want of jurisdiction and held that the, respondents had power to proceed with the inquiry into the charges.

facts.text: S. Velu Pillai, J. held Union Government had no jurisdiction for first part of charge 1, charge 2, first part of charge 3, charge 4, but had for second part of charge 1, second part of charge 3, charge 9.

anchor.surface_text: S. Velu Pillai, J. on the other hand, took the view that quasi judicial decisions became final and companyclusive if they were number set aside or modified in the manner prescribed by the statute and if the decisions are number so challenged, their companyrectness or legality must be taken to be companyclusive, and such quasi judicial decisions cannot form the subject-matter of charges in disciplinary proceedings against the appellant.

facts.text: Govinda Menon, J. agreed with Mathew, J., resulting in dismissal of writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: Velu Pillai, J. held that the Union Government had therefore numberjurisdiction to proceed with the inquiry on the first part of charge 1, charge 2, the first part of charge 3 and charge 4, but the Union Government had jurisdiction to proceed with the inquiry with regard to the second part of charge No. 1, the second part of charge No. 3 and charge No. 9.

facts.text: Appellant suspended on March 8, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: It was lastly submitted, that the order of suspension of the appellant dated March 8,1963 is number in companypliance with Rule 7 of the Rules

facts.text: Definite charges framed on June 6, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that definite charges were framed on June 6, 1963 and the Government had number authority to suspend, the appellant before the date of framing charges.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons already expressed we hold that the appellant has made out numbercase for the grant of a writ of prohibition under Art. 226 of the Constitution and the majority judgment of the High Court of Kerala dated January 5, 1966 is companyrect and this appeal must be dismissed.

issues.text: Whether the Commissioner is a corporation sole and not a servant of the Government against whom the Government has no jurisdiction to take disciplinary proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The first proposition put forward by the appellant is that the Commissioner is a corporation sole and not a servant of the Government and against a person acting in the capacity of a Commissioner the Government have no jurisdiction to take disciplinary proceedings. Reference was made to s. 80 of the Act which states that the Commissioner shall be a corporation sole and shall have perpetual succession and a common seal and may sue and be sued in his corporate name.

issues.text: Whether disciplinary proceedings can be instituted under Rule 4 of the AISDAR against a member of the Service for acts or omissions not committed in the course of employment under direct administrative control of the Government.

anchor.surface_text: Before examining this proposition it is necessary to consider rule 4 of the Rules which states Authority to institute proceedings and to impose penalty- Where a member of the Service has committed any act or omission which renders him liable to any penalty specified in rule 3 (a) if such act or omission was committed before his appointment to the service, the Government under whom be is for the time being serving shall alone be competent to institute disciplinary proceedings against him

issues.text: Whether the Commissioner was exercising quasi-judicial functions in sanctioning leases under Section 29 of the Act such that his orders cannot be questioned in disciplinary proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: We next proceed to examine the contention of the appellant that the Commissioner was exercising a quasi-judicial function in sanctioning the leases under the Act and his orders cannot therefore be questioned except in accordance with the provisions of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the rules made under Section 100(2)(m) of the Act requiring public auction apply to long-term leases exceeding 5 years falling under Section 29(1).

anchor.surface_text: We pass on to consider the next contention of the appellant that the first part of charge No.1 is not sustainable because the only rules said to have been violated was the rule regarding auction. It was argued that the rule regarding auction did not apply to long-term leases falling within the scope of s. 29 (1) of the Act

issues.text: Whether the Commissioner has power under Section 20 of the Act to initiate proposals for leases himself and then sanction them under Section 29.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the second part of charge No. 1, it was argued by the appellant that there was no prohibition in the Act for the Commissioner to himself initiate the proposal for leases and therefore the charge cannot be sustained. The question for consideration is whether the Commissioner could initiate a proposal for lease in favour of a specified individual with all the terms and conditions.

issues.text: Whether the disciplinary proceedings were validly instituted under Rule 4(1)(b) of the Rules, or barred by res judicata.
Whether suspension under Rule 7 of the AISDAR is valid before definite charges are framed and communicated under Rule 5(2).
Whether a writ of prohibition under Article 226 lies to restrain the disciplinary proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction for grant of a writ of prohibition is primarily supervisory and the object of that writ is to restrain courts or inferior tribunals from exercising a jurisdiction which they do not possess at all or else to prevent them from exceeding the limits of their jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: Proceedings initiated against appellant lack jurisdiction as no disciplinary proceedings can be taken for acts and omissions as Commissioner under Madras HRCE Act since orders are quasi-judicial and can only be impugned under the Act

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of the appellant was that the proceedings initiated against him were entirely without jurisdiction as no disciplinary proceedings could be taken against him for acts and omissions with regard to his work as Commissioner under the Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951  Madras Act XIX of 1951 , hereinafter called the Act and that the orders made by him being of quasi-judicial character can be impugned only in appropriate proceedings taken under that Act.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 4 1  does not impose any limitation or qualification as to the nature of the act or omission in respect of which disciplinary proceedings can be instituted.

arguments.claim: Act/omission reflecting on integrity can be subject of discipline even without master-servant relation

anchor.surface_text: if the act or omission is such as to reflect on the reputation of the officer for his integrity or good faith or devotion to duty, there is no reason why disciplinary proceedings should not be taken against him for that act or omission even though the act or omission relates to an activity in regard to which there is no actual master and servant relationship.

arguments.claim: Corporation sole not separate juristic person exempt from discipline

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly reject the contention of the appellant that the Commissioner has a separate legal personality as corporation sole under s. 80 of the Act and that he is exempt from disciplinary proceedings for any act or omission committed in his capacity as. Commissioner.

arguments.claim: Writ of prohibition lies only for lack/excess of jurisdiction or natural justice violation, not errors

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction for grant of a writ of prohibition is primarily supervisory and the object of that writ is to restrain courts or inferior tribunals from exercising a jurisdiction which they do not possess at all or else to prevent them from exceeding the limits of their jurisdiction. ... But the writ does not lie to correct the course, practice or procedure of an inferior tribunal,

arguments.claim: Ex.P-1 constitutes initiation of proceedings under Rule 4(1)
'Charges' in Rule 7 has wider meaning than definite charges in Rule 5(2)
No case for writ of prohibition under Art.226

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons already expressed we hold that the appellant has made out no case for the grant of a writ of prohibition under Art. 226 of the Constitution and the majority judgment of the High Court of Kerala dated January 5, 1966 is correct and this appeal must be dismissed.

holdings.text: The Commissioner is not a corporation sole with separate legal personality exempt from disciplinary proceedings under Rule 4 of the AISDAR.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly reject the contention of the appellant that the Commissioner has a separate legal personality as corporation sole under s. 80 of the Act and that he is exempt from disciplinary proceedings for any act or omission committed in his capacity as. Commissioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corporation sole is a device for property transmission, not independent juristic person; ss.80-81 vest fund without exempting officer from service discipline.

holdings.text: Rule 4(1) AISDAR permits disciplinary proceedings for any act/omission reflecting on integrity or devotion to duty, even if not in course of employment under direct Government control.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 4 1  does not impose any limitation or qualification as to the nature of the act or omission in respect of which disciplinary proceedings can be instituted. ... if the act or omission is such as to reflect on the reputation of the officer for his integrity or good faith or devotion to duty, there is no reason why disciplinary proceedings should not be taken against him for that act or omission even though the act or omission relates to an activity in regard to which there is no actual master and servant relationship.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of Rule 4 imposes no limitation on act/omission nature; test is reflection on reputation for integrity, citing Pearce v. Foster.

holdings.text: Even if sanctioning leases under s.29 Madras HRCE Act is quasi-judicial, disciplinary proceedings lie for misconduct, recklessness or abuse of power.

anchor.surface_text: Even upon that assumption we are satisfied that the Government was entitled to institute disciplinary proceedings if there was prima facie material for showing recklessness or misconduct on the part of the appellant in the discharge of his official duty. ... It is the manner in which he discharged his functions that is brought up in these proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discipline targets conduct/misconduct, not order legality (challengeable via appeal/revision); no bar if gross recklessness or disregard of conditions.

holdings.text: Rules under s.100(2)(m) Madras HRCE Act requiring public auction apply to all leases, including long-term (>5 years) under s.29(1).

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that Rule 1 made under s. 100 2  m  of the Act providing for auction applies to leases for over 5 years under s. 29 of the Act and the Commissioner had therefore no authority for sanctioning any leases without auction under s. 29 1  of the. Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 1 covers 'all leases'; trustee can auction first then seek sanction; no exception for s.29 leases.

holdings.text: Commissioner under s.20 Madras HRCE Act lacks power to initiate specific lease proposals himself; proposals must originate from trustee.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S.20 general superintendence does not empower specific proposals; s.29 implies trustee origin to avoid self-judgment.

holdings.text: Disciplinary proceedings validly instituted under Rule 4(1)(b) AISDAR by Ex.P-1 order; no formal order required.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ex.P-1 accepts prior steps and decides to proceed; Rule 4(1) needs no formal order.

holdings.text: Suspension under Rule 7(1) AISDAR valid before definite charges framed under Rule 5(2); 'charges' in Rule 7 means wider accusations/imputations.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Different language in rules; Rule 5(2) for definite charges to defend, Rule 7 for preliminary accusations justifying suspension.

holdings.text: No case made out for writ of prohibition under Art.226 to restrain disciplinary proceedings; High Court majority judgment correct.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons already expressed we hold that the appellant has made out no case for the grant of a writ of prohibition under Art. 226 of the Constitution and the majority judgment of the High Court of Kerala dated January 5, 1966 is correct and this appeal must be dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No lack/excess jurisdiction or natural justice violation; writ supervisory only, not for errors.

anchor.surface_text: It was held for instance by the Court of Appeal in The King v. North 1  that as the order of the judge of the companysistory companyrt of July 24, 1925 was made without giving the vicar an opportunity of being heard in his defence, the order was made in violation of the principles of natural justice and was therefore an order made without jurisdiction and the writ of prohibition ought to issue. But the writ does number lie to companyrect the

precedents.cited_proposition: order made without giving opportunity of being heard is in violation of natural justice, without jurisdiction, writ of prohibition ought to issue

precedents.citation: Regina v. Comptroller-General of Patents and Designs, 1 [...] 1953 2 W.L.R. 760,765

anchor.surface_text: jurisdiction  See Regina v. Comptroller-General of Patents and Designs, 1  and Parisienne Basket Shoes Proprietary Ltd. Whyte 2 . A clear distinction must therefore be maintained between want of jurisdiction and the manner in which it is exercised. If there is want of jurisdiction then the matter is companyam number Judice and a writ of prohibition will lie to the companyrt or inferior tribunal forbidding it to companytinue, proceedings therein in excess of its jurisdiction.

precedents.case_name: Regina v Comptroller-General of Patents and Designs

anchor.surface_text: jurisdiction  See Regina v. Comptroller-General of Patents and Designs, 1  and Parisienne Basket Shoes Proprietary Ltd. Whyte 2 . A clear distinction must therefore be maintained between want of jurisdiction and the manner in which it is exercised. If there is want of jurisdiction then the matter is companyam number Judice and a writ of prohibition will lie to the companyrt or inferior tribunal forbidding it to companytinue, proceedings therein in excess of its jurisdiction. The first proposition put forward by the appellant is that the Commissioner is a companyporation sole and number a servant of the Government and against a person acting in the capacity of a Commissioner the Government have numberjurisdiction to take disciplinary proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: In this companytext reference may be made to the following observations ,of Lopes, L. J. in Pearce v. Foster 1  If a servant companyducts himself in a way inconsistent with the faithful discharge of hip duty in the service, it is misconduct which justifies immediate dismissal. That misconduct, according to my view, need number be misconduct in the carrying on of the service or the business. It is sufficient if it is companyduct which is prejudicial or is likely to be prejudicial to the interests or to the reputation of the master, and the master will be justified, number only if he discovers it at the time but also if he discovers it afterwards, in dismissing that servant.

precedents.cited_proposition: misconduct need not be in carrying on of the service; sufficient if prejudicial to interests or reputation of the master
precedents.cited_holding: If a servant conducts himself in a way inconsistent with the faithful discharge of his duty in the service, it is misconduct which justifies immediate dismissal. [...] sufficient if it is conduct which is prejudicial or is likely to be prejudicial to the interests or to the reputation of the master

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly reject the contention of the appellant that the Commissioner has a separate legal personality as corporation sole under s. 80 of the Act and that he is exempt from disciplinary proceedings for any act or omission committed in his capacity as. Commissioner.

For the reasons already expressed we hold that the appellant has made out numbercase for the grant of a writ of prohibition under Art. 226 of the Constitution and the majority judgment of the High Court of Kerala dated January 5, 1966 is companyrect and this appeal must be dismissed. anchor.surface_text: Rule 4 1  does not impose any limitation or qualification as to the nature of the act or omission in respect of which disciplinary proceedings can be instituted. ... if the act or omission is such as to reflect on the reputation of the officer for his integrity or good faith or devotion to duty, there is no reason why disciplinary proceedings should not be taken against him for that act or omission even though the act or omission relates to an activity in regard to which there is no actual master and servant relationship.

For the reasons already expressed we hold that the appellant has made out numbercase for the grant of a writ of prohibition under Art. 226 of the Constitution and the majority judgment of the High Court of Kerala dated January 5, 1966 is companyrect and this appeal must be dismissed.
